ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a deeper range of independent thinking and theorizing skills. Everyone was treated as equal as class, and criticisms of archaeological papers read in class were not only welcome but highly encouraged and taken with equal value.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very interesting subject matter and the teacher was very passionate about the subject.

The main strength of the class is the huge variety of topics and interests offered, as well as the opportunities to actually make ceramics and engage physically with the material. We got to work with the best professional potter in New Haven, who is also the most generous and kind person ever. He helped us with lab sessions and worked with many students on their final projects for experimental or creative work. The only downside could be is that it was very self driven and personal interest based, so it's not an easy class to take without fully engaging in it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. It is a unique course and you learn a lot.

I would definitely recommend this class! Anne is the sweetest professor and just wants to help everyone have an interesting and important experience in the class. There are so many different angles to take for the class and you don't need to know literally anything about ceramics/archaeology/anything to take it. Like art? Take it. Arch major? Take it. Did pottery for a year when you were 10? Take it.
